1 Kinetic Energy, Power, and the Work-Energy Theorem

1.1 Kinetic Energy and Power

Definition 1.1.

Consider frame ℱa, point w, and particle y of mass my. The kinetic energy of particle y relative to point w with respect to ℱa is

Ty⁢w/a =12⁢my⁢v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a
=12⁢my⁢𝐯yy⁢w/a𝖳⁢𝐯iy⁢w/a
=12⁢my⁢‖v→y⁢w/a‖22.
Definition 1.2.

Consider particles y and w and force f→y applied to particle y. The power due to the force f→y acting on particle y relative to w with respect to frame ℱa is

Py⁢w/a⁢(f→y)=f→y⋅v→y⁢w/a.

1.2 The Work-Energy Theorem

We can relate Py⁢w/a to kinetic energy as follows. Taking the time-derivative of Ty⁢w/a=12⁢my⁢v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a and assuming that my is constant results in

dd⁢t⁢(Ty⁢w/a)=12⁢my⁢dd⁢t⁢(v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a). (1)

But this leads to the question of what is dd⁢t⁢(v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a)? Specifically, can we somehow apply a product rule to the derivative of the vector operations within the parentheses? The following fact will help us answer this question.

Fact 1.1.

The following time derivative property holds for any physical vector u→.

dd⁢t⁢(u→⋅u→)=u→∙i⋅u→+u→⋅u→∙i=2⁢u→∙i⋅u→,

where ℱi is any reference frame.

We can prove this fact by showing that u→∙i⋅u→ is the same for any reference frame ℱi. Let’s start u→∙a⋅u→ and apply the Transport Theorem to yield

u→∙a⋅u→ =(u→∙b+ω→b⁢a×u→)⋅u→
=u→∙b⋅u→+(ω→b⁢a×u→)⋅u→.

Using the fact that ω→b⁢a×u→=−u→×ω→b⁢a and resolving the physical vectors u→ and ω→b⁢a in an arbitrary reference frame ℱi, we can show that

u→∙a⋅u→ =u→∙b⋅u→−(u→×ω→b⁢a)⋅u→
=u→∙b⋅u→−(𝐮i×⁢𝝎ib⁢a)𝖳⁢𝐮i
=u→∙b⋅u→+𝝎ib⁢a𝖳⁢𝐮i×⁢𝐮i𝟎
=u→∙b⋅u→,

which demonstrates that u→∙a⋅u→=u→∙b⋅u→ and thus, the computation u→∙i⋅u→ is the same for any reference frame ℱi.

Returning to the derivative of kinetic energy in (1), we can apply Fact 1.1 to yield

dd⁢t⁢(Ty⁢w/a) =12⁢my⁢dd⁢t⁢(v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a)
=12⁢my⁢(2⁢v→y⁢w/a∙a⋅v→y⁢w/a)
=my⁢a→y⁢w/a/a⋅v→y⁢w/a. (2)

If we choose ℱa to be an inertial frame, w to be an unforced particle, and my to be constant, then Newton’s 2nd Law dictates that

my⁢a→y⁢w/a/a=f→y, (3)

where f→y is the force acting on particle y. Substituting (3) into (2) results in

dd⁢t⁢(Ty⁢w/a)=f→y⋅v→y⁢w/a=Py⁢w/a⁢(f→y). (4)

Eq. (4) is known as the Work-Energy Theorem. Note that Eq. (4) is only valid if w is an unforced particle and ℱa is an inertial reference frame.

The Work-Energy Theorem is valid for any force (conservative or non-conservative) acting on particle y. Reaction forces do not need to be considered, since there is no motion in their direction and they would disappear when taking the dot product with v→y⁢w/a.

1.3 The 4 Alternative Steps to Success in Dynamics

We can use the Work-Energy Theorem as an alternative approach to derive the equation of motion of a single degree-of-freedom particle. This method is a stepping stone towards a Lagrangian approach to dynamics, which is covered in graduate-level dynamics courses (also in Section 5 of the Forbes notes).

The 4 alternative steps to success in dynamics are

  1. 1.

    Kinematics

    1. i)

      Frames and DCMs

    2. ii)

      Angular Velocity

    3. iii)

      Position

    4. iv)

      Velocity

  2. 2.

    Kinetic Energy

  3. 3.

    Forces

  4. 4.

    Work-Energy Theorem

Example 1.1.

Consider a particle of mass my on a frictionless inclined platform attached to a spring.

The angle θ is constant, d is the constant unstretched length of the spring, and xs is the extension of the spring.

Solution.

We will first use the “4 alternative steps to success” to solve for the equation of motion of the particle.

  1. 1.

    Kinematics

    1. (a)

      Frames and DCMs:

      ℱa→𝐂3⁢(θ)ℱb.

      𝐂b⁢a=𝐂3⁢(θ)=[cos⁡(θ)sin⁡(θ)0−sin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)0001].

    2. (b)

      Angular Velocity:

      ω→b⁢a=0→, since θ is constant.

    3. (c)

      Position:

      r→y⁢w=𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0d+xs0].

    4. (d)

      Velocity:

      v→y⁢w/a =r→y⁢w∙a=r→y⁢w∙b+ω→b⁢a0→×r→y⁢w
      =𝓕→b𝖳⁢𝐫˙by⁢w
      =𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0x˙s0].
  2. 2.

    Kinetic Energy

    Ty⁢w/a =12⁢my⁢v→y⁢w/a⋅v→y⁢w/a
    =12⁢my⁢𝐯by⁢w/a𝖳⁢𝐯by⁢w/a
    =12⁢my⁢[0x˙s0]⁢[0x˙s0]
    =12⁢my⁢x˙s2.
  3. 3.

    Forces (remember that we do not need to consider reaction forces)

    Gravitational Force:

    f→y⁢g =𝓕→a𝖳⁢[−my⁢g00]=𝓕→b𝖳⁢𝐂b⁢a⁢[−my⁢g00]
    =𝓕→b𝖳⁢[cos⁡(θ)sin⁡(θ)0−sin⁡(θ)cos⁡(θ)0001]⁢[−my⁢g00]
    =𝓕→b𝖳⁢[−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)0].

    Spring Force:

    f→y⁢s=𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0−k⁢xs0].
  4. 4.

    Work-Energy Theorem

    Left-hand side of Work-Energy Theorem:

    dd⁢t⁢(Ty⁢w/a)=my⁢x˙s⁢x¨s

    Right-hand side of Work-Energy Theorem:

    (f→y⁢g+f→y⁢s)⋅v→y⁢w/a =(𝐟by⁢g+𝐟by⁢s)𝖳⁢𝐯by⁢w/a
    =([−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)0]+[0−k⁢xs0])𝖳⁢[0x˙s0]
    =[−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)−k⁢xs0]⁢[0x˙s0]
    =(my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)−k⁢xs)⁢x˙s

    Combine left- and right-hand sides:

    dd⁢t⁢(Ty⁢w/a) =(f→y⁢g+f→y⁢s)⋅v→y⁢w/a
    my⁢x˙s⁢x¨s =(my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)−k⁢xs)⁢x˙s

    Rearranging this equation gives

    x˙s⁢(my⁢x¨s+k⁢xs−my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ))=0.

    This equation must hold true for all time, so x˙s=0 is not an option if the particle is to move. Therefore, we have

    my⁢x¨s+k⁢xs−my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)=0,

    which is the equation of motion of the particle.

What if we had used the original “3 steps to success”?

  1. 1.

    Kinematics - we have already done steps i) to iv)

    1. v)

      Acceleration:

      a→y⁢w/a/a =v→y⁢w/a∙a=v→y⁢w/a∙b+ω→b⁢a0→×r→y⁢w
      =𝓕→b𝖳⁢𝐯˙by⁢w/a
      =𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0x¨s0].
  2. 2.

    Free-Body Diagram

    We already know that f→y⁢s=𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0−k⁢xs0] and f→y⁢g=𝓕→b𝖳⁢[−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)0].

    From the free-body diagram we identify the reaction force f→y⁢r=𝓕→b𝖳⁢[fb⁢1y⁢r00].

  3. 3.

    Newton’s 2nd Law

    f→y⁢s+f→y⁢g+f→y⁢r =my⁢a→y⁢w/a/a
    𝓕→b𝖳⁢([0−k⁢xs0]+[−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)0]+[fb⁢1y⁢r00]) =𝓕→b𝖳⁢[0x¨s0]
    [−my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)+fb⁢1y⁢r−k⁢xs+my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)0] =[0x¨s0]

    This gives two equations:

    −my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ)+fb⁢1y⁢r =0
    −k⁢xs+my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ) =x¨s

    The first equation tells us the expression for the reaction force: fb⁢1y⁢r=my⁢g⁢cos⁡(θ). The second equation is the equation of motion of the particle:

    x¨s+k⁢xs−my⁢g⁢sin⁡(θ)=0,

    which matches the result obtained using the “4 alternative steps to success”.

Note that the “4 alternative steps to success” are only applicable to particles with a single degree of freedom (i.e., a particle that has only a single equation of motion). The “4 alternative steps to success” do not provide an expression for reaction forces, which may or may not be important, depending on the application.
